8. MARTHA EMELINE THOMPSON (JACOB2, GIDEON1) was born May 25, 1836 in Tennessee and died February 11, 1920 in Reagan Wells Tx. She married (1) THOMAS B. HAMMER August 20, 1855. She married (2) LAWRENCE PIKE HEARD June 04, 1858 in Utopia Tx, son of Wyatt Heard and Mary Reeves

 

Notes

Martha Emeline Thompson came to the Sabinal Canyon with her brother Gideon, in 1852. They came from Hawkins County Tennessee via Arkansas. In Arkansas, Gideon married Margaret O'Bryant Slavin, the widow of David Slavin. Gideon and Margaret and four of their children along with his sister Emeline were the first white family to come west of the German settlement of D'Hanis. Capt. William Ware was the first settler, but he brought his family later. (from A.J Sowell's "Texas Indian Fighters") Martha first married Thomas Hammer and they had one son, Thomas Harney born in 1856. Thomas Hammer erected a stage stop and store on the west bank of the Sabinal River at Sabinal in 1854. Although the Second US Cavalry had a camp directly across the river, Hammer was killed by either (1) Mexican Bandits or (2) Indians in 1857. The ruins of the store can still be seen at the edge of Highway 90 West of Sabinal, almost hidden by mesquite brush.

Martha married Lawrence Pike Heard on June 4, 1858 and they lived for several years in Utopia before moving to the Dry Frio Canyon. They are both buried in the Heard Cemetary at Reagan Wells Texas.

 

Child of Martha Heard and Thomas Hammer is:

i. THOMAS HARNEY HAMMER, b. May 30, 1856; d. January 07, 1913.

 

Children of Martha Heard and Lawrence Heard are:

. ii. MARY JANE HEARD , b. March 17, 1859; d. December 18, 1934.

iii. MARTHA EMALINE HEARD , b. April 27, 1861; d. May 08, 1944.

iv. HENRY LAWRENCE HEARD, b. July 04, 1865; d. August 01, 1953, California.

v. ANNIE ELLA HEARD , b. April 04, 1868; d. May 02, 1926.

vi. WYATT HUBBARD HEARD, b. April 21, 1872 d. January 11, 1926, Reagan Wells Tx.

vii. CHARLES AUGUSTIN HEARD, b. August 20, 1875, Utopia Tx; d. April 20, 1961,

viii. DEXTER HEARD, b. 1878; d. 1878.

  

Generation No. 4

STATE GOP TO DECIDE WHETHER TO FILE COMPLAINT OVER NANCY THOMPSON AD

The Nebraska Republican Party is deciding whether to file a complaint with the Federal Election Commission over television ads promoting Nancy Thompson for Congress.

The ads violate FEC regulations and federal law because the committee which paid for the ad does not exist, stated State Republican Party Chairman David Kramer.

The television ads in question airing on cable and network affiliates in Omaha, includes a disclaimer stating that it was paid for by Friends of Nancy Thompson. According to the Federal Election Commission, no such committee exists.

The disclaimer in the ad raises serious questions about whether the ad was appropriately paid for and authorized by the candidate, Kramer said.

Kramer said the ad should be removed immediately.

This is an important race, and all parties must play by the rules, Kramer said.

Kramer said If Thompsons campaign paid for the ad, then the campaign has violated the law. If the ad was paid by a third party, then that entity has violated the law.

If that is the case Kramer said, the FEC should investigate whether the Thompson campaign illegally coordinated the activity.

Saturday, February 28, 2004 | Updated Twice Weekly

 

3 Minutes of Stardom

 

Karaoke still rolling with 20 years of fame

By Bob Behme / Staff Writer

ARROYO GRANDE -- Unlike most Japanese imports, karaoke has become so thoroughly Americanized we think of it as our invention.

In Pismo Beach, it dominates Thursday nights at Harry's Night Club & Beach Bar, and at Bill's Place in Arroyo Grande, it draws crowds of happy aficionados five nights a week.

There are even specialists who can bring karaoke -- complete with special music, flashing lights and a sound system that delivers more decibels than the ear can comfortably accommodate -- straight to your office, birthday party or bar mitzvah.

It's at sanctuaries like Harry's and Bill's Place that true karaoke can be found. There, the music is supplied by trained professionals, and one of the oldest, biggest and best-known is the San Luis Obispo-based California Karaoke, owned by "Doc" and Nancy Thompson. It is their show that keeps crowds returning to Bill's Place.

For anyone unsure what karaoke is, it has been called the new grass-roots music, Mitch Miller for the 21st century, a high-tech form of audience participation and the perfect choice for anyone who likes to sing but is afraid he or she can't.

Paulina Burton, a mortgage broker with Chase Manhattan, has been singing karaoke for five years. She follows the Thompsons from venue to venue and is a Bill's Place regular. Her photo is on the wall, in a place reserved for "Star Performers."

"There is a sense of family here," Burton said. "Doc, Nancy and other regulars are just like family."

Debi Makley, an Arroyo Grande housewife, has been a regular for four years. Until three weeks ago, she was afraid to sing.

"I finally got up the nerve, did it and it's great," Makley said.

Now, Makely can be counted on to belt out two or three songs a night.

August Gabriel, who manages the Nipomo Swap Meet, has a special reason for attending. "I don't drink, but I love to sing in bars," Gabriel explained. "Karaoke is the answer."

Critics see karaoke as the musical equivalent of Andy Warhol's 15 minutes of fame, and Thompson agrees.

"Everyone wants to be an entertainer, and karaoke gives them their three minutes of stardom," he said.

The Thompsons have a library of nearly 4,500 tunes from country-Western and blues to rock, rap and reggae. Each song is specially recorded without a vocalist but with words, digital graphics and special effects dubbed in that show up on a television screen the singer can see.

According to Thompson, when a tune is played, the result is good enough to showcase even the most inexperienced singer.

The concept began in 1984 in a converted boxcar in Okayama Prefecture, Japan. Its coined name combines two Japanese words, "kara" and "oke," meaning "empty orchestra" when combined. But as Thompson points out, it is not history but conviviality that draws the crowds.

The rotation of singers is determined by their arrival. Their names are written on slips and placed on a small board.

"It's like a batting order, one singer after the other," Thompson said. "Even on a busy night, each person gets to perform several songs."

While karaoke makes all singers sound good, some seem to have a natural magic.

Rory Aylward, who's nickname is "Hawk," is a television producer from Morro Bay ("Silent Night" shown on Hallmark Theater is one example of his work). One night at Bill's Place, Aylward gave his rendition of the Sinatra standard "The Best Is Yet to Come." His voice, phrasing and rhythm were so close to vintage Sinatra that it seemed almost as though "Old Blue Eyes" had returned.

 

 

"Sax," who wouldn't give his real name, is so passionate about karaoke he drives all the way from Atascadero to sing at Bill's Place in the Village of Arroyo Grande. A Japanese import some claim was actually inspired by a 1950s American television show, karaoke offers amateur singers a moment in the spotlight. " TPR photo by Glenn Bolivar.
 
Joining voices in a karaoke duet at Bill's Place on a recent Monday night are Debi Makley, left, and Nancy Thompson. TPR photo by Glenn Bolivar.
 
On any given night, the Thompsons play 30 to 40 songs, and according to Nancy Thompson, country and Western tunes top the karaoke charts.

"Favorites include anything by Garth Brooks, 'Boot Scootin' Boogie' by Brooks & Dunn and 'Sweet Home Alabama' by Lynrd Skynrd," she said.

The Thompsons are improbable entrepreneurs. They grew up in Fresno and spent time working in the mental health field. Doc has a doctorate and was a certified psychotherapist for 25 years. Originally he was program director of mental health in Fresno County, and when he moved to private practice, Nancy came with him as office manager.

"We went through a series of events that resulted in a complete change in lifestyle," Thompson said.

The two moved to the Central Coast and, in 1990, heard about karaoke. Almost overnight, Doc bought the necessary equipment. Now, the couple operates five fully equipped systems with clients from Atascadero to Arroyo Grande. Sometimes they work together, as at Bill's Place, and at other times Doc handles one venue while Nancy handles another.

On occasion, they'll even perform. Nancy has a large repertoire, but Doc classifies himself as "a three-song wonder."

"I can do 'Mack the Knife,' 'Love on the Rocks' and 'Blueberry Hill,'" he said.

Their schedule, as well as show times, can be viewed on their Web site, californiakaraoke.com. Shows at Bill's Place run Friday through Tuesday.

One busy night, bartender Ronny Goodgine, prompted by a happy crowd, proclaimed Bill's Place "the karaoke capital of the world."

On a busy night, with a good song playing, a singer at the microphone and line dancers boogying across the floor, one can almost believe it.

 Nancy Thompson

Homework


Important Dates

General Announcements

Nancy Thompson--Director, Shared Schooling

I first came to South Whidbey in 1993 to be a support to families who had chosen to home school their children. The program was called the Off Campus Extension Program, and we were located at the Wellington Day School in Clinton.

After two years, the Off Campus Program moved to Bayview, where we were located for two more years. When Bayview needed more space, we moved to House of Prayer, where we were located for three years. When House of Prayer needed its space back, we moved to the three portables behind South Whidbey High School.

There are about 115 students in the Off Campus program at this time.

Carroll County, New Hampshire

Simon Hill Road,
Effingham NH

A NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET
    Rating: 
     
    USA. 1984.
    Director/Screenplay - Wes Craven, Producer - Robert Shaye, Photography - Jacques Haitkin, Music - Charles Bernstein, Mechanical Effects - Jim Doyle, Makeup Effects - David Miller, Production Design - Gregg Fonseca. Production Company - New Line Cinema/Media Home Entertainment/Smart Egg Pictures.
    Cast:
    Heather Lagenkamp (Nancy Thompson), Robert Englund (Fred Krueger), Ronee Blakely (Marge Thompson), Johnny Depp (Glenn Lance), John Saxon (Lieutenant Thompson), Amanda Wyss (Tina Grey), Nick Corri (Rod Lance)
     

    Plot: Teenager Nancy Thompson finds that she and a group of friends are all experiencing identical nightmares wherein they are pursued by a burn-scarred figure in a hat who wields a razor-tipped glove. And when the figure starts to mutilate them in their nightmares, they wake up to find cuts and burns on their skin in reality too. Next Nancys friend Tina is killed in the waking world as she is savagely dismembered by the figure in her dreams. Haunted by the same figure, Nancy discovers that he is Fred Krueger, a child molester that their parents dragged away and burnt alive after he was acquitted on a technicality and who has now returned to exact revenge on their children. Nancy desperately tries to stay awake and find a means of combating Krueger.

    The success that transformed a pizza-faced child molester into the cult anti-hero of the 1980s is a wild unlikelihood that could surely only have happened in the horror genre. A Nightmare on Elm Street may well have been the single most influential horror film of the 1980s. The film spun a whole series of sequels - seven at current count (see below) and created a unique new boogie man in the character of Freddy Krueger, who appeared on T-shirts, lunchboxes, model kits, even became a poster pin-up figure. Furthermore it inspired a whole genre of horror films which rested in a blurred dividing line between dream and reality and/or featured a boogie man returned from the grave to slice people up. It made Robert Englund, surely the horror genres equivalent of Billy Idol and one of its worst actors, into a cult star. It also transformed the career of Wes Craven, then a director who had made a couple of strong ultra-violent indie horror films - The Last House on the Left (1972) and The Hills Have Eyes (1977) - and was searching around trying to break into the mainstream, into a major name in horror. And the spawning of the Elm Street films into a franchise gave New Line Cinema the financial clout to move from a minor studio into a major frontline player throughout the next decade.

    Wes Cravens films all resonate with a sense of the tenuousness of reality and the importance of dreams. The Last House on the Left, Deadly Blessing (1981) and Deadly Friend (1986) all have striking dream sequences. Subsequent Craven films such as The Serpent and the Rainbow (1988) and Shocker (1989) feature villains who inhabit dreams and places of the imagination more so than the real world, while The People Under the Stairs (1991) features a couple who have transformed an ordinary house into a kind of rubber reality that pops up with trapdoors and slides when least unexpected. And Craven films of the 1990s such as Wes Cravens New Nightmare (1994) and Scream (1996) and sequels have become preoccupied with meta-fiction - they are films where the dividing line between movie fiction and the audience watching the film is constantly being broken down and blurred. But Cravens oneirological horrors and the blurrings of reality and imagination receive their most striking and most undiluted airing here in Elm Street. Although at the time rather than any grandly metaphysical grappling with the nature of dream and reality, Craven was only drawing upon the 1980s boogie man figure that had been popularized through the success of Halloween (1978) and Friday the 13th (1980) and numerous sequels and imitations of either. And for all that, Craven received surprising number of problems in trying to find financing for Elm Street, with it being rejected by all the major studios. It was eventually made on only a surprisingly low $1.8 million budget where it was construed as no more than another variant on Halloween.

    The sequels diluted the character of Freddy Krueger until he was no more than a badass Wile E. Coyote figure popping up and dispatching teenage victims with a campy one-liner. The sequels seem less directed than they are stage-managed by the effects and makeup people. Elm Street by contrast maintains Krueger as an effectively threatening presence, largely by keeping him almost entirely silent throughout. There is almost nothing in the way of novelty effects set-pieces here and those that do turn up tend to be rather cheesy-seeming in comparison to those in the sequels. Despite this Elm Street is a dozen times more effective than almost all of Elm Streets II through VI placed together. Craven evinces a genuine wildness to the visions he unleashes - the shadowy figure of Krueger pursuing victims with huge extended six-foot long clawed arms; soon-to-be teen idol Johnny Depp being sucked down into his bed, along with his stereo and tv, and spat out in a gusher of blood that sprays against the ceiling; the wall above Heather Lagenkamps head bulging out with a pair of hands as she sleeps; or the outrageous image of the clawed hand surfacing between her legs as she doses off in the bath and then tries to drag her down into a gaping black hole; and especially the dispatch of Amanda Wyss, slashed to bloody pieces while being dragged around the walls and roof of her bedroom.

    And yet for all that and considering the reputation the film holds, it also has an irritatingly unhoned crudeness at times. The dialogue and characters never rise much above being the random victims of the average Friday the 13th film. Heather Lagenkamp gives an awful vain and snooty performance which is a major factor in working against the films sympathy. Craven also demonstrates the irritating willingness to throw away the self-created rules of the game he has set up for the purpose of a twist ending which reveals the nightmare isnt over (although he did later insist that the ending wasnt his but was forced on him by the studio). Nevertheless the film has a haunting effectiveness in Cravens genuinely unworldly visions.

    The film makes an interesting comparison with Dreamscape (1984), released only a few months before this, which played the same idea with an sf angle but to far more banal ends. Two other interesting progenitors are Don Coscarellis Phantasm/The Never Dead (1979), a film which exists in a confidently surreal blurring line between dream and reality, and the little seen The Sender (1982) about a psychic psychiatric patient who has the ability to insert himself into peoples dreams.

    The sequels are: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part II: Freddys Revenge (1985), A Nightmare on Elm Street III: The Dream Warriors (1987), A Nightmare on Elm Street IV: The Dream Master (1988), A Nightmare on Elm Street: The Dream Child (1989), Freddys Dead: The Final Nightmare (1991) and Wes Cravens New Nightmare (1994). Craven had script input on the third and wrote and directed the last. New Nightmare is the only one that is worth watching, a film where Craven does remarkable things in setting it in the real world where actress Heather Lagenkamp, playing herself, finds her life being invaded by the characters from the films. In the 1990s New Line Cinema purchased the rights to the Friday the 13th series and for some time there was the long-rumoured idea of a Freddy vs Jason film, uniting the two boogiemen. Freddys glove made a cameo appearance in Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (1993) and the full-fledged results finally emerged with Freddy vs. Jason (2003). Englund later hosted Freddys Nightmares: A Nightmare on Elm Street - The Series (1988-9) which only used Freddy Krueger as the host of a horror anthology series, although the first episode did offer a Freddy origin story.

    Wes Cravens other genre films are:- the brutality and revenge films The Last House on the Left (1972) and The Hills Have Eyes (1977); the suburban witch film Summer of Fear/Stranger in the House (1978); Deadly Blessing (1981) about murders around a religious cult; the comic-book adaptation Swamp Thing (1982); The Hills Have Eyes Part 2 (1985); Deadly Friend (1986) about a teen inventor who revives his girlfriend from the dead; The Serpent and the Rainbow (1988), a strikingly beautiful film about Haitian voodoo; Shocker (1989) a campily incoherent film about an undead executed killer; The People Under the Stairs (1991); Wes Cravens New Nightmare (1994); the Eddie Murphy vampire comedy Vampire in Brooklyn (1995); and the slasher deconstruction trilogy of Scream (1996), Scream 2 (1997) and Scream 3 (2000).
     

    Copyright Richard Scheib 1990

Posted on Tue, Oct. 05, 2004

Candidate for Clay County Assessor


NAME: Nancy Thompson

OFFICE: Clay County Assessor Candidate

DATE OF BIRTH: 9-2-1960

EDUCATION: University of Missouri - Kansas City, J.D., 1985

William Woods College, B.S., 1982, Major: Political Science

OCCUPATION: Ensz & Jester, P.C., Of Counsel, 2001- present, City of Gladstone, City Counselor, 1993-2000, Thompson & Thompson, Partner, 1985-1993

FAMILY: I have been married to my husband Randall for 20 years. We have two children: Chas, age 17, is a Senior at Winnetonka High School; Jake, age 15, is a Sophomore at Winnetonka High School.

1. Previous experience in elective or appointive office, or as a candidate for office.

Clay County Health Center Board of Trustees, elected, 2002-present

City of Gladstone City Counselor, appointed - 1993-2000 (from time to time would serve as Acting City Manager in the absence of the City Manager)

Clay County Constitution Commission - 2001/2002, appointed

Missouri Municipal Attorneys Association - President 1996

National Association of Master Appraisers, Associate Member

Kansas City Chapter of International Association of Assessing Officers, Subscribing Member

Missouri Mappers Association, Subscribing Member

Missouri Bar Association, Local Public Law Committee

Children's Mercy Hospital Regional Council

2. Why do you seek this office?

I have a strong desire to use my skills and background to improve our community and seek this office out of a sincere commitment to public service. I would not be running for this office if I thought the current Assessor was doing a good job for our community. The current Assessor has put party politics above the needs of the taxpayers, risking millions of dollars in funding for our schools and communities. One year ago, assessments on new construction were off over $30 Million. Two years ago, errors by the Assessor in reporting assessed valuation figures to the State of Missouri cost the Liberty School District over $3.2 Million in funding for its schools. In the past 8 years, the current Assessor has failed to implement the TerraScan computer assisted mass appraisal system and her own reports admit that she is years behind in correct tax assessments. I think we, as citizens of Clay County, deserve better representation and should hold the current Assessor accountable.

Clay County needs change in the Assessor's Office and I am a well qualified alternative to the mismanagement that has existed during the last 8 years. I am an attorney with an extensive background in real estate transactions and a member of the Master Appraisers Association, the Kansas City Chapter of International Assessing Officers, and the Missouri Mappers Association. Previously, I served seven years as an appointed professional department head in the City of Gladstone. When I left the City to devote my energy to raising two children, Mayor Dan Bishop and the City Council awarded me a key to the City for “outstanding professionalism and contributions to the success of the City of Gladstone.” I am frequently asked to provide educational seminars at statewide conferences on the powers, duties and legal responsibilities of elected and appointed officials. I want to use my background, qualifications and problem-solving skills to make a difference in our county and will be a strong voice for the taxpayers.

3. If you are an incumbent, what accomplishments are you most proud of? How do you feel you could improve your performance if re-elected?

n/a

4. If you are a challenger or non-incumbent, how would you administer the office differently than the incumbent? Please give a detailed description of your ideas.

Currently, the use of technology to allow public access to maps and records maintained by the Assessor's office is severely lacking. These records should be made available to the public through the Internet. The current Assessor time and again has promised to provide on-line access to the taxpayers, but has failed to implement such a plan — although other counties throughout the State of Missouri are providing this important service to their taxpayers. Computerization and public access are two of my highest priorities if elected and I will ensure that Internet access is provided in a timely fashion.

I will also provide better service to constituents by implementing internal procedures that will check for accuracy and consistency in reporting of assessment calculations. I will listen to the needs of the citizens and encourage public participation in the assessment process. I will develop and open lines of communication with schools, cities, library districts, fire protection districts, health center and other office holders. I will foster a professional work environment by initiating internal office procedures for employees that focus on consistency in employee hiring, training, and evaluation. I will work to lessen the tax burden on seniors with fixed incomes by actively providing information to our seniors on programs available to hold the line on higher taxes and by being an advocate on their behalf with the state legislature.

5. What are your top four priorities for improving Clay County's governmental operation through your office?

A. To improve communication and access to maps and public information maintained by the office through the Internet and to be responsive to other direct requests by the public for information in a timely manner;

B. To improve accuracy of reports and estimates published by the office as well as ensure that reviews and reassessments are up to date by implementing computer software that is compatible with other offices within the county, which will assist in the appraisal process;

C. To communicate and cooperate with other officeholders, schools and communities to increase efficiency and provide improved service to the public at a lower cost to taxpayers; and

D. To establish consistent training programs for employees, to require all appraisers within the office to be state certified and to create a professional environment within the assessor's office where employees are encouraged to perform at the highest level.

6. How would you improve the image and credibility of Clay County government?

The political squabbling in Clay County needs to end for the overall good of our community. One of my top priorities is to work to improve cooperation and communication among officeholders. While serving in Gladstone government, I had the opportunity to work in a professional environment and I will bring that experience to the county. I will work every single day to do a good job for citizens of Clay County and will build partnerships with the other elected officials in the county. I will draw on my record of integrity and professionalism in government to lead by example and be an advocate for the taxpayers.

7. As Clay County adds more than 3,000 people a year, how can the county improve services to its taxpayers?

Clay County should have greater coordination between officeholders to eliminate duplication, share information and work together to operate more efficiently as it provides services to the public. There is currently little cooperation between elected offices on computer program compatibility, record keeping, cross-training of employees, employment policies, or equalized pay scales; and there is no opportunity for departmental transfers and promotions. I would like to see Clay County operate under a team approach in budget adoption and office administration which encourages the officeholders to think and act in terms of what is good for the county as a whole rather than how to get more for their individual office.

As it faces a budget crunch, Clay County needs to be fiscally conservative and focus on core services and infrastructure. It was irresponsible for some officeholders (including my opponent) to vote themselves an increase in pay while complaining about a lack of funds to provide needed services to the citizens of Clay County.

8. Do you support or oppose a bistate tax for funding regional arts projects and programs, as well as improvements at the Truman Sports Complex?

Clay County does not exist in a vacuum. We are a part of the much larger Kansas City Metropolitan community. I believe that the success and prosperity of our county is dependent on the overall success and prosperity of the entire metropolitan area. Strong regional arts and recreational opportunities are key components of a successful metropolitan community and as an individual I have contributed privately to such activities on a regional basis. It is up to the citizens of Clay County to decide whether a sales tax is the appropriate method to fund enhancements and additional cultural opportunities within the metro area. I will support what the majority of the taxpayers in Clay County decide and I am not actively supporting or opposing the bistate tax initiative.

9. Do you favor or oppose public incentives, such as tax abatement and tax increment financing, to encourage development in Clay County?

I support the concept of using tax incentives to encourage redevelopment projects; however, I believe the definition of “blighted” that is used to qualify projects for such incentives has been stretched so that the real intent and purpose of the original legislation has been lost. I do not support use of tax incentives for development of new residential projects and/or commercial projects on previously undeveloped land — particularly when there is merely a shift in resources from one location to another and not a net gain to the public at large.

Regardless of my personal concerns regarding use of public incentives, I know the laws concerning the use of public incentives and have experience in monitoring and tracking the growth in assessed valuation that is used in repayment of the fees due under the financing agreements. In the past, calculations on tax increment financing projects coming out of the Assessor's office have been inaccurate and incomplete, resulting in financial harm to our schools and local communities. When the use of tax incentives is approved I will be actively involved to ensure that such projects are tracked and reported accurately to the taxing jurisdictions as well as the State of Missouri.

One couple gives up their day jobs for music

NOW THEY TRAVEL THE COUNTRYSIDE BRINGING TUNES TO THE MASSES

San Luis Obispo
By Carol Roberts
The Tribune - September 21, 1999

    Nancy and Doc Thompson of San Luis Obispo don't think what they're doing now is so far removed from the way they made their livings years ago.
   " The people who participate say it's therapy," said Doc Thompson, 59, a former Fresno psychologist who specialized in multiple personality disorders.
    He met Nancy, 50, "who was once painfully shy," when she worked with her mother in a residential treatment program for adolescent girls.
    "We help make people feel good about themselves."
    The Thompsons and their staff put on 16 scheduled karaoke shows a week at Bill'S Place in Arroyo Grande, Rose's Landing, Happy Jack's and Otter Rock Cafe in Morro Bay, Harry's in Pismo Beach, the Z Club in San Luis Obispo, the Merrimaker in Los Osos, Wilson's Lounge in Paso Robles and the Old Town Saloon in Clovis. They also do weddings, parties and travel to the Bay Area and Los Angeles with their enthusiasm and equipment.
    Their foray into karaoke was almost an accident.
    Stressed out by their day jobs in the late 1980s in Fresno, where both grew up, they decided to move permanently to Cayucos, which up until then had only been a weekend getaway. They opened a video store, lived upstairs and rented out movies for a few years.
    One day Doc Thompson let a friend put a karaoke machine in the store. Nancy Thompson pooh-poohed its existence and pledged she'd never play with it. She thought it was a useless acquisition at a time when money wasn't all that plentiful. "I was so mad at him," she said recently.
    Her husband didn't "play with it" either for several months. Then late one night, alone downstairs, he turned it on and was inspired by the background sounds of professional musicians. He sang "Mack the Knife." Nancy heard
him from upstairs and stomped on the floor with approval. California Karaoke was born. At first they took their equipment out to bars and restaurants for free to entice would-be singers and convince owners such entertainment would boost coffers. "They were right," said Susie Stephenson, who runs Bill's Place in Arroyo Grande. Her bar is packed on karaoke nights, especially Friday and Saturdays.
   "Soon the Thompsons started getting paid by the owners. They added staff and equipment because they couldn't be in several places at once putting on the shows. They're scheduled for certain hours, but often end up staying longer. (For specifics, try www. californiakaraoke.com).
    Doc Thompson admits he isn't much of a singer himself but he enjoys announcing, working the equipment and the camaraderie of the crowds
   " Nancy, who Doc Thompson describes as "once painfully shy" is the one 'with the great voice who'll put her arm around a newcomer to help carry the tune. She's the heart and soul of the show."
    Though maybe once shy, Nancy Thompson said music has been a lifetime love. She won a trip to Hawaii in 1975 by appearing on the old national TV show "Name That Tune." She named "My Wild Irish Rose," after hearing only the first note of the melody.
    The couple, now settled in a spacious mobile home with Nancy's mother right across the street, enjoy reminiscing about the past but prefer to talk about the present.
    They're leading the good life now, Doc Thompson said. Their son, Jon, 32, a civilian flight chief at Edwards Air Force Base, has added a daughter-in-law and two grandchildren to the family. Their in-house "family" includes Lester, a macaw, and Bob, a silver-crested cockatoo.
    They're "having a ball" with their job, said Doc Thompson. 'We're providing what everyone needs -- love, fulfillment, variety and change."

California Environmental Protection Agency



This Site My CA

 

Enforcement Training

Section 12812.2 of the California Government Code. This section requires the California Environmental Protection Agency (Cal/EPA) Office of the Secretary to develop a program to ensure that all the boards, departments, offices, and other agencies that implement Cal/EPA's laws and regulations "take consistent, effective, and coordinated compliance and enforcement actions." The statute specifically requires that, "The program shall include training and cross-training of inspection and enforcement personnel"

The Cal/EPA Inspector Certification Program was created to implement the training component of the statute. All Cal/EPA boards, departments, offices, and local implementing agencies have contributed to its development. The program consists of the Basic Inspector Academy, the annual Environmental Cross Media Enforcement Symposium, and the Inspector Training Clearinghouse. The Academy provides baseline training for new inspectors, and the Symposium provides continuing education for all inspectors.

The staff resources for the Inspector Certification Program are housed in the California Air Resources Board (ARB), Enforcement Division, Training Section.

Inspector Training Clearinghouse

The Cal/EPA Clearinghouse for Inspector Training provides a one-stop-shopping source for all kinds of information associated with environmental inspector training. Courses offered by both state and local agencies are represented. For more information, please visit the Cal/EPA Inspector Training Clearinghouse.

Course 310: The Cal/EPA Basic Inspector Academy

The Basic Inspector Academy (BIA) is designed to teach environmental agency inspectors and other compliance professionals core knowledge and skills, and to encourage cross-media awareness needed to conduct quality inspections. The objective of the program is to ensure consistent, effective, and coordinated compliance and enforcement actions to protect public health and the environment by the state, local, and tribal agencies implementing environmental laws or regulations within the jurisdiction of the California Environmental Protection Agency.

The BIA is taught by a multi-disciplinary team of instructors, environmental professionals, and attorneys, encompassing a cross-media approach to environmental issues. The course is approximately 40 hours of classroom instruction for training environmental agency inspectors and enforcement personnel.

The following topics are covered through lecture, interactive exercises and a mock inspection:

Roles and Responsibilities of the Cal/EPA Agencies

  • Role of the Inspector
  • Environmental Law
  • Environmental Chemistry
  • Inspection Overview
  • Personal Safety in the Field
  • Interviewing Skills
  • Evidence and Sample Collection
  • Elements of a Violation
  • Resolving Violations
  • Working with Task Forces
  • Report Writing
  • Report Analysis
  • Testimony Skills

2005 Academy Schedule

Sacramento January 24-28, 2005
Fresno September 12-16, 2005
TBA October 31-November 4, 2005

Registration Information

Academy enrollment is restricted to state and local environmental regulators within the State of California, only. You are encouraged to register as early as possible because space is limited. There are four ways to register:

1) Telephone (916) 322-2227
2) FAX

 (916) 323-3303, Attn: Nancy Thompson
3) Email nthompso@arb.ca.gov
4) US Mail

Nancy Thompson

Air Resources Board 
Enforcement Division, 5th floor 
P.O. Box 2815 
Sacramento, CA 95812

Please use the registration form provided below. The form cannot be saved using Acrobat Reader, so please print the form for mailing or faxing. If you have the full version of Adobe Acrobat, you can save and attach your completed registration form to nthompso@arb.ca.gov. All registrations will be accepted in the order received. If you do not receive confirmation two weeks prior to the course, please contact Nancy Thompson.

Course Fees $50.00/week

PAGE 6
FROM THE THOMPSON FAMILY HISTORY
AS WRITTEN BY JAMES A THOMPSON JR IN 1971.

          Lemuel Thompson (another of Trimmigan Sr.'s brothers) in his will mentions a Nancy Thompson who was probably the daughter of his brother Theophilus. Here is a written copy of the original will as it is recorded:



                          Lemuel Thompson

              Robeson Co., North Carolina

              Prob. 1820


                    Sons: Nathan Thompson

                                    Daniel

                    Daughter: Sarah Barnes

                    Neice: Nancy Thompson (daughter of Theophilus Thompson)



Wit:             Samuel Jenkins

                    John Thompson

                    Ken Black

                                                            Son:   Nathan Thompson, Executor


 


          There is believed to have been a daughter of Theophilus (brother of Trimmigan, Sr.) named Nancy. On Page 7 is a copy of a marriage document between John Williams and Nancy Thompson dated March 18, 1825. It is signed by Theophilus Thompson, brother of Trimmigan, Sr.

THOMPSON FAMILY GENEALOGY





AMOS THOMPSON



Amos THOMPSON lived in Virginia. Although we had hoped to be able to trace him back to a American patriot, we found that he fought on the side of England in the War of Independence. He died at the age of only 19 after marrying Martha "Patty" Strother and fathering one son, Little Berry THOMPSON who was born in 1780 just one year before Amos THOMPSON was killed.



LITTLE BERRY THOMPSON



Little Berry THOMPSON was born in 1780, and died in 1839. He married UNKNOWN and had one child: Zelphy THOMPSON.



ZELPHY THOMPSON



Zelphy THOMPSON was born in 1800. She married John FENNER, and had one child:
Isaiah FENNER b. 1821. She then married David LEATHERMAN. Children by David LEATHERMAN were:

Mary L. LEATHERMAN b. 1840
Peter N. LEATHERMAN b. 1835
L. Z. LEATHERMAN b. 1846
George Gordan LEATHERMAN b. 1835, d. 1850.



LITTLE BERRY THOMPSON





Little Berry THOMPSON then married Patience ? [last name Unknown] before 1805 and had the following children:

1. Biddy THOMPSON b. 1805, d. 1850, and was married [1] Samuel PICKENS and then to [2]Ransom GRAHAM

2. Nancy THOMPSON b. 1806, d. 1853, married twice [1} Benjamin MORRIS, [2] David K. WALL.

3. Sarah THOMPSON b. 1807 d. 1850, married [1] Charles WOOD, and [2] Edward JENNINGS.

4. Martha THOMPSON b. 1809, d. 1837, married [1]James B. WILES, [2] Mark CAWBITT.

5. Charity THOMPSON b. 1811, d. 1837, married [1] Abner SMITH, [2] Peter LEATHERMAN.

6. Delila THOMPSON b. 1812, d. 1848, married Edward DUFF.

7. Amos Berry THOMPSON b. 1815, d. 1891, married Isabelle Jane GAYLE.

8. Patience Ann Jane THOMPSON b. 1819, d. 1853, married Stephen J. TICKELL.

9. Richard Samuel THOMPSON I b. 1821 in Wilkinson County, Mississippi, died March 1849 in Catahoula Parish, Louisiana. He married [1] A. H. KELSEY, and [2] Lucy Ellen MOSELY on October 8, 1846 in Wilkinson County, Mississippi.



BIDDY THOMPSON





Biddy THOMPSON was born in 1805 and died in 1850. She married Samuel PICKENS. It is not known is they had any children. Then she married Random GRAHAM who died in 1870. Their children were:

1. Milford GRAHAM.

2. James A. GRAHAM.

3. Melissa GRAHAM.

4. Florence GRAHAM.



NANCY THOMPSON

Published Tuesday
October 26, 2004

Lee Terry up 2-to-1 in latest W-H Poll

BY HENRY J. CORDES

  

WORLD-HERALD STAFF WRITER

RELATED LINKS

»

»
Lee Terry for Congress

»
Jack Graziano for Congress

»
Nancy Thompson for Congress

»
Jeff Fortenberry for Congress

Steve Larrick for Congress

»
Project Vote Smart: Nebraska congressional candidates

»
Dante Salvatierra for Congress

»
Donna J. Anderson for Congress

»
Roy Guisinger for Congress

Republican U.S. Rep. Lee Terry enjoys a 2-to-1 lead over Nancy Thompson in his bid for re-election, despite an aggressive campaign by the Democratic state senator from Papillion, a new World-Herald Poll has found.

World-Herald Poll ©
If the election for U.S. representative were held today:

1st District
Would you vote for Matt Connealy, Jeff Fortenberry or someone else?
Connealy (D)
 38%
Fortenberry (R)
 42%
Other

Unsure *

Margin of error: ±6.2 percentage points
*Totals don't add up to 100 percent because of rounding differences.

2nd District
Would you vote for Nancy Thompson, Lee Terry or someone else?
Thompson (D)
 30%
Terry (R)
 60%
Other
 2%
Unsure

Margin of error: ±4.4 percentage points

3rd District
Would you vote for Donna Anderson, Tom Osborne or someone else?
Donna Anderson (D)
 8%
Tom Osborne (R)
 86%
Other
 1%
Unsure
 5%
Margin of error: ±6.2 percentage points
Source: Poll of likely voters by RKM Research and Communications


The survey of voters in the 2nd District, which includes Douglas County and eastern Sarpy County, showed Terry leading Thompson 60 percent to 30 percent. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.4 percentage points.

Terry's campaign manager said the 2nd District poll indicates that voters want to keep their congressman.

"Nancy Thompson is a very credible candidate and has run a good race," David Boomer said Monday. "But people have looked at both candidates and are very satisfied with Lee's leadership."

Thompson campaign manager Jason Burke said the Democrat's polling shows a far closer race. If the campaigns truly were that far apart, he said, Terry wouldn't be spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on advertising targeting Thompson in the final weeks of the campaign.

"The proof for us is in our own polling and his actions," Burke said.

The World-Herald Poll found the 1st District race between Democrat Matt Connealy and Republican Jeff Fortenberry too close to call. The results show why the eastern Nebraska race has become part of the national battle for control of the U.S. House of Representatives.

As expected, 3rd District U.S. Rep. Tom Osborne again is running up a lead of blowout proportions, with the football coach-turned-politician leading Columbus Democrat Donna Anderson nearly 11-to-1.

In the 2nd District, Terry never has received less than 60 percent of the vote in winning three terms in Congress. But it was thought that Thompson, who has worked harder and raised far more money than any of Terry's previous Democratic challengers, could make it tougher for Terry this time.

She has aggressively criticized Terry on support for veterans, the budget deficit and breaking a pledge to serve only six years.

Terry, who initially planned to run a campaign without mentioning his opponent, struck back with ads criticizing Thompson for voting to raise taxes in the Legislature and missing votes while running for Congress.

Thompson's campaign efforts have not shaken Terry's support among Republicans, who backed him 83 percent to 11 percent in the poll.

Meanwhile, more than one in three Democrats were backing Terry. Overall, more voters said they had an unfavorable opinion of Thompson, 38 percent, than favorable, 29 percent.

In the 1st District, the poll of likely voters found Fortenberry leading Connealy by 4 percentage points in the race to replace recently retired U.S. Rep. Doug Bereuter, a Republican. Nearly one in six 1st District voters were still undecided.

Such numbers give Democrats hope that they could claim the district that has been represented by Republicans for four decades. Connealy said he was particularly encouraged by poll figures indicating that he was running even with Fortenberry in the Republican's home base of Lincoln and leading 2-to-1 among independents.

"We come from a little town and the minority party and don't have as much money," said Connealy, a state senator and farmer from Decatur. "I know how to work. We're going to keep it up."

Fortenberry, a former Lincoln city councilman, said he is encouraged that every poll to date - even Connealy's - has shown him leading. He said he will continue the grass-roots campaigning that raised him from relative obscurity when he first announced for Congress earlier this year.

"I don't take anything for granted," he said. "We're going to work hard to the end and continue to energize new people."

The close results in the 1st District poll are reflected in the large amounts of money Republicans and Democrats in Washington are spending to help their candidates. The parties usually poll races themselves and invest resources in those seen as competitive.

The Republican National Congressional Committee, political arm of the House GOP leadership in Washington, came in two weeks ago with a $300,000-plus ad blitz against Connealy. It criticized the lawmaker for supporting tax increases and backing proposals it says encourage illegal immigration.

The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee last week responded, spending at least $200,000 on advertising that questioned Fortenberry's work ethic while a member of the Lincoln City Council. "It's a great opportunity for us," the Democratic committee's Stacy Kerr said of the race.

The 1st District poll found Fortenberry favored by 42 percent of respondents to 38 percent for Connealy. Fifteen percent were undecided. The Fortenberry-Connealy difference was within the poll's margin of error of 6.2 percentage points.

Democrats have hoped Connealy's farm background could help him cut into the traditional big registration advantage Republicans enjoy in rural areas. The poll suggests he is having some success. Fortenberry led him 42 percent to 35 percent outside of Lincoln.

Within the capital city - which traditionally leans Democratic but is also Fortenberry's home - the poll found the two nearly even, Connealy leading 44 percent to 43 percent.

The poll was taken Oct. 15 through 20, and mostly completed before Connealy and the Democratic committee began running ads critical of Fortenberry. At that point, Connealy already had faced more than a week of advertising from the GOP.

In the sprawling 3rd District, the poll found Osborne leading Anderson 86 percent to 8 percent. The margin of error for the 3rd District survey was 6.2 percentage points.

Director, CEO - Dr Charlie Clutterbuck

Dr Charles Clutterbuck PhD, MSc, BSc, PGCE, FRSA
 (PGCE = Teachers Certificate) (FRSA is Fellow of Royal Society of Arts)

Dr Charles Clutterbuck is one of the world's leading authorities on the environment. With 30 years experience, he dedicates his life to working, researching, promoting and advising the government, environmental and labour groups eg: He co-wrote the original "Workers Education and the Environment" learning materials for the Intenational Labour Organisation. He retired as a Seniour Lecturer from Blackburn College and worked as a Senior Training Advisor at Goundwork Blackburn, when he wrote for an Awarding Body a level 3 award "Certificate in Environmental Practice".

He is an appointed member of the UK government's 'Advisory Committee on Pesticides' and an invited member of the government's Trade Union Sustainable Development Advisory Committee (TUSDAC) with particular responsibility for Skills Development. Charlie is a member of the Advisory Group for the Co-op on pesticide reduction and the vice-chair of their Advisory Group on Responsible Retailing. He represents the TGWU farmworkers/TUC the Health & Safety Executive Agriculture. He is a Temporary Adviser to World Health Organisation for online materials for Health, Environment & Safety in the workplace, and their world Food and Nutrition programme,

As part of the build up to the World Summit, Charlie was nominated to the RSA "Sustainable Development Award" and came in 5th in a worldwide vote (nomination and full coverage of award winners).

He has three degrees in agricultural science, a BSc (Agricultural Zoology) from Newcastle University, an MSc (Applied Plant Science) and a PhD (on the effects of herbicides on soil fauna) from Wye (now Imperial) College, London University. He also has a Teaching Certificate and a "D32" (now 'Assessor Unit'). He has co-written two books about food and pesticides, was Chair of Lancashire College of Agriculture, and is now an Honorary Visiting Fellow in the Department of Health Management & Food Policy, City University, London and an Associate of the Centre for Environmental Protection, London Metropolitan University.

  Director, Learning Advisor - Nancy Thompson

Nancy Thompson, MA (Env Ed), Cert Ed, AMIEMA

Nancy Thompson, Director and Training Advisor for EPAW, spent 15 years working on environmental conservation initiatives before entering the teaching profession. She was involved in project work with Wildlife Trusts, Local Authorities and as a Country Park Ranger. Her work included managing diverse projects ranging from research on the regional distribution of bumble bees and plant galls to rescuing great crested newts from quarry sites. Nancy was an active local Field Club member, guided walk leader and has made several radio broadcasts and written journal articles for various wildlife publications.

In addition to teaching environmental sciences & Environmental Management she has developed both courses and materials for Lancaster University, Workers Education Association, and several F & HE Colleges in the North West. She was a member of the Management Charter Initiative working group that developed the national vocational Environmental Management Standards. Nancy was Environmental Projects Officer for Blackburn College responsible for developing their first draft EMS, and moderator of a 2 year Europe wide environmental training development project. She is a qualified vocational training assessor and verifier

Nancy is an Associate Member of the Institute of Environmental Management and Assessment and has extensive experience in training people to implement environmental management systems both from an educational perspective and practical application as a consultant with Groundwork Trust BEA Blackburn.

She authored the UfI Learn Direct programme 'Environmental Management Toolkit’ to enable businesses to introduce an EMS. and has reviewed environmental publications for Gee Publishing and the Engineering Employers Federation.

For her Masters degree in Environmental Education, Nottingham Trent University [1999-2001], Nancy used the development process and trials of the epaw Environmental Practitioner Programme as her action research to discover 'What educational processes enable employees to contribute to improved environmental and sustainable development practices in the workplace?'
